titleStmt.title: News article "Fifty Years of Freedom" written by an unknown author. No date given.
titleStmt.author: Author unknown

publicationStmt.p: This document forms part of the project "Editing the Earth M.M. White Collection" at the University of North Florida.

msIdentifier.repository: University of North Florida, Thomas G. Carpenter Library Special Collections and Archives

msContents.summary: Author writes about the celebration of Emancipation day in Edward Waters College and Bethel Baptists Institutional Church.

objectDesc.p: A one-page clipping of a typewritten news article.

editorialDecl.p: This file was transcribed and encoded according to the editorial criteria of the project "Editing the Eartha M.M. White Collection." Using the various options encoded within <choice> elements, this file enables the viewing of a diplomatic transcription and a regularized reading text.

div.head:
Celebration Largely Attended Last
Night and at Edward Waters Col- lege in the Afternoon.

div.p:
The celebration of Emancipation day
was held in the chapel of Edward Wa-
ters College yesterday afternoon by the
faculty and students, and last night
in Bethel Baptist Institutional Church,
under the auspices of the Lincoln Me-
morial Association and the Colored
Citizens’ Protective League.

At the collegcollege, many from the city at-
tended and the exercises by the stu-
dents, with good music, were especially
enjoyed. The principal address was
delivered by Prof. J. A. Lankford, M.
M. S., supervising architect of the A.
M. E. Church.

Prof. Lankford’s address was quite
embracive, taking in the history of his
race in ancient and modern times. The
achievements of his race in the past
fifty years were dwelt upon with great
emphasis, enumerating what has been
done educationally, industrially and re-
ligiously. This address was received
with much applause and the celebra-
tion at the college was a most credit-
able success.

Bethel Baptist Church last night was
filled. Mr. A. L. Lewis presided. The
choir of the church led in the singing
“America,” the large congregation
joining in. Prayer was offered by the
Rev. R. L. Brown, followed by singing.
The Emancipation Proclamation was
read by Mrs. Edna Yates-French. A
selection was rendered by the choral
class of Cookman Institute.

“Harriet Beecher Stowe, a Forerun-
ner of Emancipation,” was delivered.
